Project.summary: This supplement evaluates the potential impacts on the aquifer environment, soils, ecology, and public health, as well as the potential for disproportionate impacts on minority or low-income populations. It also assesses the potential for cumulative impacts associated with other past, present, or reasonably foreseeable future actions. The NRC staff finds that all of the impacts on the resources evaluated would be SMALL, including the impact of potential radiological and nonradiological releases from the repository on the aquifer and at surface discharge locations of groundwater beyond the regulatory compliance location. The peak estimated annual individual radiological dose over the one-million-year period at any of the evaluated locations is 1.3 mrem [0.013 mSv], which is a small fraction of the background radiation dose and much less than the NRC annual dose standards.

projectMetadata.name: Geologic Repository for the Disposal of Spent Nuclear Fuel and High-Level Radioactive Waste

Project.summary: This supplement evaluates the potential environmental impacts on groundwater and impacts associated with the discharge of any contaminated groundwater to the ground surface due to potential releases from a geologic repository for spent nuclear fuel and high-level radioactive waste at Yucca Mountain, Nye County, Nevada. It assesses potential radiological and nonradiological impacts over a one million year period on the aquifer environment, soils, ecology, and public health, as well as the potential for disproportionate impacts on minority or low-income populations. Additionally, it evaluates the potential for cumulative impacts associated with other past, present, or reasonably foreseeable future actions.
This supplement assesses the potential groundwater and surface discharge impacts over a period of approximately one million years after repository closure.

This supplement evaluates the potential environmental impacts on groundwater and impacts associated with the discharge of any contaminated groundwater to the ground surface due to potential releases from a geologic repository for spent nuclear fuel and high-level radioactive waste at Yucca Mountain, Nye County, Nevada. It supplements the DOE’s 2002 and 2008 Environmental Impact Statements in accordance with NRC's 2008 Adoption Determination Report.

Chapter 1-6 describes the potential impacts of repository contamination of groundwater and from the surface discharge of groundwater. Chapter 4 describes cumulative impacts associated with potential repository contamination of groundwater and the surface discharge of that groundwater. Chapter 5 provides a summary of the NRC staff’s impact findings.

This supplement describes the potential impacts under different climate conditions and groundwater-use rates in the Yucca Mountain area, providing a representative range of credible future climates and human activities affecting groundwater.

Organization.name: SNDWR
Organization.fullName: State of Nevada Division of Water Resources

Project.summary: This supplement presents additional information about the impacts of potential repository contamination of groundwater, as well as the potential impacts associated with the discharge of contaminated groundwater to the surface.

The U.S. Department of Energy’s (DOE’s) Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) and Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement (SEIS) described the affected environment from the Yucca Mountain repository site to the location of the reasonably maximally exposed individual (RMEI) in the Amargosa Desert.

The document discusses the adjudicatory process and various decisions related to the Yucca Mountain repository project. It includes details about the NRC's review, the DOE's license application, and subsequent court and commission directives.

Organization.name: US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
Organization.fullName: US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit

Project.summary: The proposed repository site at Yucca Mountain is in volcanic tuff and lies above part of the large volcanic aquifer in the Central Death Valley Subregion. The Subregion contains the aquifers likely to be affected by contaminants released from the repository. Some small portion of groundwater flow from beneath Yucca Mountain may enter the Southern Death Valley Subregion to the south and east. The third subregion, to the west and north of the Central Death Valley Subregion, is the Northern Death Valley Subregion.

The NRC staff assumes the current population and its distribution, as well as the current range of human activities, will continue for the entire period analyzed in the supplement. This is consistent with NRC and EPA regulations, which direct DOE not to project changes in society, the biosphere (other than climate), human biology, or increases or decreases in human knowledge or technology.

The groundwater flow path from Yucca Mountain passes through the unsaturated zone, reaches the uppermost volcanic aquifer, and then flows east to southeast to join the larger volume of groundwater flowing southward along Fortymile Wash towards Amargosa Desert. The transition from the Fortymile Canyon Section to the Amargosa River Section coincides approximately with the regulatory compliance location.

The affected environment for contaminants released from the repository includes the aquifer itself as well as sites where groundwater could discharge to the surface, either through pumping or natural processes.

Project.summary: The analysis discusses the groundwater flow paths from Yucca Mountain, particularly focusing on the Funeral Mountain Section and the springs in the Furnace Creek area. It highlights the likelihood of groundwater flow towards the Funeral Mountains and the springs in Death Valley National Park, influenced by fractured carbonate rock and the absence of pumping in Amargosa Farms.

The document discusses the characteristics and interactions of different aquifers in the DVRFS, including the alluvial aquifer, carbonate aquifer, and volcanic tuff aquifer. It also describes the geological structures and groundwater flow dynamics.

Organization.name: NWRPO
Organization.fullName: Nye County Nuclear Waste Repository Project Office

Project.summary: An alternative flow path for groundwater from Yucca Mountain is along the trace of the Amargosa River to Alkali Flat. Updated information on aquifer units in the Funeral Mountains suggests this path is less likely, but some flow in this direction cannot be ruled out. The groundwater flow path continues through various sections of the Southern Death Valley Subregion and ends at Badwater Basin in Death Valley.

The document discusses the potential impacts of different climate states on groundwater flow and contaminant transport in the Yucca Mountain region. It considers both natural climate variations and human-induced climate change over a one-million-year period.

The document discusses the groundwater flow path from Yucca Mountain to Death Valley, focusing on the Amargosa River and its surrounding basins. It describes the intermittent nature of the Amargosa River and its flow patterns, especially in relation to the proposed repository at Yucca Mountain.

The document discusses the groundwater flow paths from Amargosa Farms through the Funeral Mountains to various discharge points, including Furnace Creek springs and Middle Basin in Death Valley. It also covers the use of the DVRFS model to analyze potential contaminant transport paths.

The document discusses the impact of groundwater pumping on Devils Hole and the Amargosa Farms area, as well as the understanding of past and future climates in the southern Great Basin region, which includes the Yucca Mountain site.

projectMetadata.name: Yucca Mountain Project
projectMetadata.location: Yucca Mountain, Mojave Basin and Range

Project.summary: The region south of Yucca Mountain, where the surface water discharge locations are located, is within the Mojave Basin and Range ecoregion. This ecoregion is composed of broad basins and scattered mountains that are generally lower, warmer, and drier than those of the Central Basin and Range located north of the Mojave Basin and Range ecoregion.

Present-day natural surface discharge sites from the groundwater system in the desert of the southern Great Basin cover a spectrum of types, from seeps onto the ground surface (springs) to wet or dry playas. Groundwater discharges as springs where the water table reaches the ground surface. Wet playas occur in low areas where the water table is below the ground surface to depths of less than 5 m [16 ft]. Dry playas occur where the water table is at greater depths. Surface discharges in desert environments can vary seasonally and year to year, depending on precipitation and other factors.

projectMetadata.name: Death Valley Regional Groundwater Flow System

projectMetadata.location: Death Valley Regional Groundwater Flow System

Project.summary: The affected environments considered in this supplement are outside of the nominally controlled area considered by DOE in its previous assessments, and could include historic and cultural resources. Present-day sites of natural surface discharge near or along the flow path from Yucca Mountain to Death Valley are described, including springs at Furnace Creek and Middle Basin.

This supplement evaluates the potential environmental impacts on groundwater and impacts associated with the discharge of any contaminated groundwater to the surface due to potential releases from a geologic repository for spent nuclear fuel (SNF) and high-level radioactive waste (HLW) at Yucca Mountain, Nye County, Nevada.

projectMetadata.name: Groundwater Pumping in the DVRFS
projectMetadata.location: Amargosa Valley, Pahrump Valley, Penoyer Valley

Project.summary: The document discusses groundwater pumping in the DVRFS, focusing on Amargosa Valley, Pahrump Valley, and Penoyer Valley, highlighting the usage for irrigation, domestic, and commercial purposes.

Organization.name: State of Nevada Division of Water Resources

Project.summary: The text describes the natural discharge sites for groundwater potentially contaminated by releases from a repository at Yucca Mountain, focusing on the Furnace Creek/Middle Basin of Death Valley and other minor sites. It also discusses paleodischarge sites that could become active under cooler/wetter climates.

projectMetadata.name: Yucca Mountain Groundwater Analysis
projectMetadata.location: Yucca Mountain, Amargosa Farms, Furnace Creek Springs

Project.summary: Analysis of potential impacts on groundwater flow and contaminants from Yucca Mountain to Amargosa Farms and Furnace Creek Springs under various future climate scenarios.

Significant landscape changes may occur within the Mojave Basin and Range ecoregion in the short term and long term in response to climate change. Modeling suggests that in response to possible near-term climate change, the lowest-elevation basins throughout the ecoregion could transition from warm desert scrub into relatively barren areas, with the expansion of some desert playas and the transformation of the mixed salt-desert scrub vegetation type. These changes, driven by surface discharge, potential contaminant concentration, and discharge environment, are unpredictable but not necessary for assessing impacts.

projectMetadata.name: State Line Deposits Water Table Study

Project.summary: The document discusses the water table in the State Line Deposits area and the Franklin Well area, including historical well measurements, potential groundwater drawdown effects, and vegetation.

This chapter assesses the potential impacts for environments from contaminants released from the proposed repository at Yucca Mountain. The affected environment includes the aquifer and the surface discharge sites beyond the regulatory compliance location at approximately 18 km along the groundwater flow path from Yucca Mountain.

This page discusses the water discharge dynamics at Alkali Flat, including surface discharge, chemistry of the water, vegetation distribution, and discharge estimates for various locations in the Amargosa Farms area.

The document discusses the analysis methods used to address the uncertainty in future pumping projections at Amargosa Farms, considering both present-day and future cooler/wetter climates. The analysis includes methods for contaminant transport and environmental impact assessment over 10,000 and one million years.
The document discusses the State Line Deposits area, groundwater flow from Yucca Mountain, and paleodischarge deposits in the Amargosa Desert and Crater Flat.

The document discusses the impact of additional groundwater pumping on the lower carbonate aquifer, the effects of climate change on future groundwater flow paths, and water use and quality in areas south of Amargosa Farms along the flow path to Death Valley.

This supplement provides updated impact information for groundwater pumping in the Amargosa Farms area, and provides impacts at sites of natural surface discharge along the flow path between the regulatory compliance location and Death Valley along the Yucca Mountain groundwater flow path. The impacts include those from both radiological and nonradiological contaminants at pumping locations (Amargosa Farms) and at natural discharge locations for one million years; results at earlier times are also provided.

The NRC staff concluded that a description was needed of the accumulated amounts of radiological and nonradiological contaminants from the repository that may enter the groundwater over time, as well as a description of where those contaminants would travel along the flow path.

The document discusses the groundwater flow models and surface discharge environments related to the Yucca Mountain Project. It highlights the flow paths, potential water table rises, and the impact of future wetter climates on various locations such as Crater Flat, Alkali Flat, and Death Valley.

This section discusses the impacts of contaminants from the Yucca Mountain repository on the groundwater system and the Amargosa Farms community, including radiological and nonradiological dose pathways.

The document discusses the evolution of groundwater pumping models and their impact on groundwater conditions in the Amargosa Farms area from 1913 to 2003. It includes updates and analyses of pumping rates and their effects on the environment.
The document discusses the behavior of different contaminants in the aquifer environment, focusing on their accumulation and migration patterns over time, particularly at Amargosa Farms.

The document discusses the groundwater quality and potential impacts of a proposed repository at Yucca Mountain, focusing on areas such as Amargosa Farms and Death Valley National Park. It includes analysis cases to assess the impacts of potential changes in the groundwater environment due to factors like climate state and regional pumping.

Further context for the dose values provided in this supplement is the average annual dose estimated for the regulatory compliance location from the 2008 SEIS. DOE calculated maximum average annual dose for the RMEI at the regulatory compliance location to be 0.24 mrem/yr for the initial 10,000 years after repository closure, and the maximum average annual dose one million years after closure to be 2.0 mrem/yr. The NRC staff has found DOE’s calculations to be acceptable as part of its safety evaluation. The regulatory safety standards in 40 CFR Part 197 and 10 CFR Part 63 for the RMEI are 15 and 100 mrem/yr for the 10,000 and one million year periods, respectively.

This document discusses the potential impacts of contaminant discharge from Yucca Mountain to various locations such as Alkali Flat, State Line Deposits/Franklin Well area, Furnace Creek, and Middle Basin of Death Valley. The analysis includes the potential pathways and discharge rates under different climate scenarios.
Dose History of Selected Radionuclides at Amargosa Farms for the Present-Day and Cooler/Wetter Climates.

This page discusses the calculation of contaminant concentrations in the exposure pathways, dose and body intake, and accumulation in soils. It also covers the analysis of radiological and nonradiological contaminants in the releases from the repository, focusing on those that reach the Amargosa Farms area and are significant contributors to dose.

This section describes the accumulation of contaminants in soils at Amargosa Farms. The NRC staff calculated soil contaminant concentrations using the irrigation recycling model. The primary radionuclides that would accumulate in the soil are U-238, U-235, Np-237, Pu-242, U-233, and Th-230. Nonradiological contaminants show the greatest calculated concentrations at one million years. The NRC staff concludes that the accumulation in soils at Amargosa Farms of radiological and nonradiological material released from the repository would be minimal.

Overall, the concentrations of radionuclides and other contaminants from the repository for groundwater at Amargosa Farms are uniformly very low, with calculated peak concentrations for various contaminants being well below EPA standards.

projectMetadata.name: State Line Deposits/Franklin Well Area Project

Project.summary: The document discusses the aquifer environment and potential impacts of groundwater discharge at the State Line Deposits/Franklin Well area. It compares the environment and impacts with those at Amargosa Farms, noting that the impacts at the State Line Deposits/Franklin Well area would be less due to additional dispersion and decay of contaminants.

projectMetadata.name: State Line Deposits/Franklin Well Area Project
projectMetadata.location: State Line Deposits, Franklin Well Area

Project.summary: This page discusses the peak annual dose and body intake estimates for various radionuclides at the State Line Deposits/Franklin Well Area under cooler/wetter climate conditions over different time periods.

This section describes the accumulation of repository materials in soils at the State Line Deposits/Franklin Well area for the wetter climate. The NRC staff uses two approaches to estimate the soil concentration of contaminants for the cooler/wetter climate.

The document discusses the discharge of contaminants from the Yucca Mountain repository to the aquifer environment, and their potential impact on areas such as Furnace Creek and Death Valley over a one-million-year period.
Peak annual dose estimates and dose history for selected radionuclides at the Furnace Creek Area under different climate conditions.
Analysis of radiological and nonradiological material released from the repository to the Amargosa Farms area, including impact assessments for different climate scenarios.

The document discusses dose adjustments for secular disequilibrium, dose conversion factors for present-day and future climates, and peak doses of radionuclides at Amargosa Farms. It also considers potential health effects from nonradiological contaminants.
Analysis of soil concentrations of radiological and nonradiological contaminants at the State Line/Franklin Well Area using Evaporite and Salt Marsh Soil Models over 10,000 to 1 million years.
Dose history for selected radionuclides and total dose at Middle Basin for present-day and cooler/wetter climate states.

This section describes the accumulation of potential contaminants from the repository in soils at Middle Basin or Furnace Creek. The concentrations of contaminants in soil and evaporite deposits within the wet playa are calculated using the estimated concentrations of the contaminant and TDS content of the groundwater.

The document discusses the estimated average concentrations of radiological and nonradiological contaminants in groundwater discharging to the surface at the Furnace Creek area. The analysis considers different climate states and their impact on contaminant transport and concentration over time.

The document discusses the peak daily intake of molybdenum (Mo) at Furnace Creek and Middle Basin under different climate scenarios, as well as the radiological and nonradiological contaminants in these areas.

The biosphere dose pathways used in this supplement for the Death Valley locations include external exposure, inhalation of soil/evaporite particulates and water vapor from evaporative coolers, and ingestion of water and soil/evaporite particulates. Ingestion of locally-grown crops, animal products, and fish was not included as a pathway for the natural discharge areas of Death Valley due to minimal agricultural production. The principal radionuclides contributing to dose at Furnace Creek are Tc-99 and I-129.

The document discusses the impact of radiological and nonradiological contaminants from the Yucca Mountain repository on various locations, including Amargosa Valley, Furnace Creek, and Middle Basin of Death Valley. It evaluates the peak doses and body intake values over extended periods, concluding that the impact to public health would be small.
The impacts to public health from radiological and nonradiological contaminants associated with natural groundwater discharges at Furnace Creek and Middle Basin of Death Valley would be SMALL.

The NRC staff evaluated the potential for ecological impacts from radionuclides and chemical constituents at potential locations for surface discharges of groundwater to the environment. The impacts on nonhuman biota from radiological contaminants at locations like Amargosa Farms, State Line Deposits/Franklin Well area, and Furnace Creek/Middle Basin were found to be small.

The analysis focuses on the impacts of groundwater flow from Yucca Mountain affecting nearby population centers, specifically Amargosa Valley in Nye County, Nevada, and Death Valley National Park in Inyo County, California. The NRC staff evaluated potential environmental justice impacts on minority and low-income populations in these areas.

The study discusses the accumulation of radiological and nonradiological contaminants in Middle Basin and Furnace Creek areas. It highlights the impact of Tc-99, I-129, and Mo under different climate scenarios.

Comments.content: Because there is very little accumulation of radiological contaminants (only Tc-99 and I-129, and at very low levels) in soils at Middle Basin or Furnace Creek, and because accumulations of the one nonradiological contaminant present (Mo) is likely to be elevated only in barren and uninhabitable portions of these areas, the NRC staff finds that soil impacts from radiological and nonradiological contaminants associated with natural groundwater discharges at Middle Basin and Furnace Creek would be SMALL.

projectMetadata.name: Death Valley National Park Environmental Impact
projectMetadata.location: Death Valley National Park, Inyo County, California

Project.summary: The document discusses the impacts on minority and low-income populations at Death Valley National Park, focusing on groundwater flow from Yucca Mountain and its effects on the Timbisha Shoshone Tribe community in the Furnace Creek area.

The NRC staff acknowledges the sensitivities and cultural practices of the Timbisha Shoshone Tribe concerning the use and purity of springs in the Furnace Creek area. The NRC staff determines that there would be no disproportionately high and adverse human health or environmental effects from uses or discharges of groundwater flowing from the repository on minority or low-income segments of the populations in the Amargosa Valley area and in Death Valley National Park.

The ADR addresses DOE's assessment of impacts on historic and cultural resources, including Native American viewpoints. The DOE's EISs indicate ongoing efforts to comply with laws affecting Native American cultural practices, and establish mitigation advisory boards.

The NRC staff notes that the agreement scope does not include areas outside the Operator-Controlled Area and that the agreement states that any impacts outside this area would need to be addressed separately. The DOE programmatic agreement focuses on proposed activities within the state of Nevada, and some of the affected areas identified in this supplement are in California. The NRC staff concludes that DOE would need to assess whether further consultation and investigation are necessary to account for potential impacts on cultural resources that may be located in areas where groundwater discharges to the surface.

The NRC staff concludes that the impact to the accessible environment, soil impacts, and potential public health impacts from radiological and nonradiological contaminants in the Furnace Creek and Middle Basin areas would be SMALL. DOE's analysis finds no high and adverse potential impacts to the general public or minority/low-income populations from groundwater contaminants following the closure of the Yucca Mountain repository.

DOE’s historic and cultural resource analyses in its EISs for the proposed repository at Yucca Mountain focused on the repository site and the surrounding controlled area. The 2002 EIS and the 2008 SEIS provide evaluations of potential environmental impacts on historic and cultural resources, including updates and expanded regions of influence.
This chapter evaluates the cumulative impacts on groundwater, considering both direct and indirect impacts when combined with other actions affecting the same resources.

The NRC staff reviewed cumulative impacts analyses in DOE’s EISs to supplement NRC staff’s findings. The spatial boundary for cumulative groundwater impacts includes the area of the aquifer beneath Yucca Mountain and along its flow path, while the temporal boundaries extend to one million years after repository closure.
Chapter 2 provides descriptions of the resource areas that could be affected by potential groundwater contamination from the repository and surface discharges of contaminated groundwater.

The document discusses the cumulative impacts on groundwater from past, present, and future actions related to the proposed nuclear waste repository in Nevada, as analyzed by the DOE in their 2002 and 2008 EIS and SEIS documents.
Project.capacity: 70,000 metric tons of spent nuclear fuel (SNF) and high-level radioactive waste

Project.summary: The NRC staff assessed potential incremental groundwater impacts at various locations, including the State Line Deposits/Franklin Well area, Furnace Creek Springs area, Middle Basin area, and Alkali Flat. The findings indicate that the incremental groundwater impacts at these locations would be SMALL.

The NRC staff discusses the limitations on the emplacement of radioactive waste at the Yucca Mountain repository, including the prohibition of more than 70,000 metric tons of heavy metal or high-level radioactive waste until a second repository is in operation. The NRC staff also evaluates the region of influence and cumulative impacts on groundwater.

Organization.name: NNSS
Organization.role: Potential contributor to cumulative groundwater impacts

Organization.name: Beatty low-level waste site
Organization.role: Potential contributor to cumulative groundwater impacts

Project.summary: The NRC staff evaluated the description of other land uses for the repository site provided in DOE’s SAR (DOE, 2008b), and conducted an independent evaluation of the Yucca Mountain site description as part of its review. The NRC staff concludes that these activities would not result in groundwater contamination and would not contribute to cumulative groundwater impacts.

The NRC staff reviewed DOE's assessment of the potential cumulative groundwater impacts from the NNSS and Beatty sites, concluding that these sites are unlikely to contribute significant nonradiological contamination to groundwater. Radiological impacts would be mitigated by dispersion and radioactive decay.
Assessment of potential cumulative impacts from Federal, non-Federal, and private actions contributing to groundwater contamination at NNSS and Beatty waste management and disposal sites.

Organization.name: Nevada Department of Health and Human Services
Organization.fullName: Nevada Department of Health and Human Services

Project.summary: DOE/NNSA reports that tritium was detected in two offsite wells. Tritium concentrations were found to be below the EPA's MCL. The NRC staff concludes that tritium contamination would not contribute cumulatively with radionuclides from the repository.

Organization.name: DOE/NNSA
Organization.fullName: Department of Energy/National Nuclear Security Administration

Project.summary: This section discusses cumulative impacts on groundwater and from pumping and irrigation in the affected environment described in Chapter 2. The impacts at Amargosa Farms are reported separately from the natural discharge locations because Amargosa Farms is not a natural discharge location and the evaluation of impacts involves a consideration of different environmental processes and pathways. As in Chapter 3, the analysis of impacts considers both the present-day and future cooler/wetter climates.

projectMetadata.name: Environmental Impact Analysis
projectMetadata.location: Amargosa Farms, State Line Deposits, Franklin Well area, Furnace Creek/Middle Basin, Alkali Flat

Project.summary: The NRC staff concludes that the potential for ecological impacts from radiological and nonradiological contaminants at all of the surface discharge locations would be SMALL.

The NRC staff supplements DOE’s assessment by evaluating groundwater impacts at Amargosa Farms and at natural surface discharge locations in Death Valley. Further supplementation is needed to describe actions planned or occurring since 2008 that could contribute to cumulative groundwater impacts.

The NRC staff has identified regional mining activity and NNSS tritium releases as additional actions or impacts that could contribute to groundwater impacts at surface discharge locations. The cumulative impacts on groundwater at these surface discharge areas would be minimal and would not noticeably alter groundwater characteristics beyond the effects attributed to the repository alone.

The NRC staff assessed human health impacts from nonradiological contaminants by comparing daily intakes with EPA’s Oral Reference Dose standard. The incremental impact of contaminants released from the repository on public health at the Amargosa Farms area would be SMALL.

The NRC staff assessed potential incremental public health impacts at various locations including State Line Deposits/Franklin Well area, Furnace Creek Springs, Middle Basin areas, and Alkali Flat. The cumulative impacts on soils and public health are considered minimal.

The NRC staff assessed the potential environmental impacts on nonhuman biota and ecological resources at Amargosa Farms, concluding that the impacts would be small or undetectable. They also evaluated environmental justice concerns, finding no disproportionate impacts on minority or low-income populations.
Assessment of potential cumulative impacts on historic and cultural resources, environmental justice, and groundwater in Death Valley National Park.

The NRC staff evaluates potential radiological and nonradiological impacts at various locations including Middle Basin, Furnace Creek Springs, and Alkali Flat. The estimated doses for Middle Basin are below natural background levels and NRC standards, and impacts at Alkali Flat are considered to be minimal due to limited exposure pathways.

The NRC staff evaluates the cumulative impacts for direct and indirect impacts identified in Chapter 3 when aggregated with the impacts of other actions that could affect the same resources. The NRC staff also evaluates how its findings in Chapter 3 and cumulative impact findings in Chapter 4 affect the conclusions provided by DOE in its assessment of cumulative impacts on groundwater in Chapter 8 of its EIS (DOE, 2002) and Chapter 8 of its SEIS (DOE, 2008a).

projectMetadata.name: Environmental Impact Assessment
projectMetadata.location: State Line Deposits, Franklin Wells area, Middle Basin, Furnace Creek Springs, Alkali Flat

Project.summary: The NRC staff evaluates the potential environmental impacts of both radiological and nonradiological contaminants on nonhuman biota in various locations under present-day and future wetter climates for both 10,000-year and one-million-year timeframes. The analysis concludes that the impacts would be minimal and not noticeably affect non-human biota beyond the potential impacts from the repository alone.

This report supplements the U.S. Department of Energy’s (DOE’s) 2002 Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) and 2008 Supplemental EIS (SEIS) for a proposed geologic repository for the disposal of spent nuclear fuel and high-level radioactive waste at Yucca Mountain, Nevada, by providing additional analyses of impacts on groundwater and from surface discharges of groundwater. The chapter summarizes the impact conclusions from the NRC staff’s supplemental analyses and evaluates whether any of these supplemental analyses have identified any additional unavoidable adverse impacts, considerations regarding the relationship between local short-term uses of the environment and the maintenance and enhancement of long-term productivity, or irreversible and irretrievable commitments of resources.
This analysis discusses contaminants that could be released from the repository into the groundwater, impacting water quality. It includes both radiological and nonradiological materials.

DOE/NNSA would add new projects at the NNSS, including activities in nonproliferation, counterterrorism, high-hazard experiments involving explosives and nuclear materials, research and development, testing, renewable energy, and waste disposal. Activities at the Tonopah Test Range include weapons testing, experiments, research and development, and infrastructure improvements.
Safety Evaluation Report Related to Disposal of High-Level Radioactive Wastes in a Geologic Repository at Yucca Mountain, Nevada

Project.summary: The NRC staff evaluated the TSPA model and found it acceptable for use in safety evaluations. The TSPA model calculates the movement of contaminants beyond the regulatory compliance location, incorporating various transport processes and considering future climate change scenarios.

This appendix provides a description of the analysis methods used to determine impacts to affected environments beyond the regulatory compliance location. It extends the framework used in previous analyses to analyze both radiological and nonradiological contaminants for one million years after closure of the repository, using transport and biosphere models.

The TSPA model used for the license application was derived using the draft rule (70 FR 53313) for the licensing of a geologic repository at Yucca Mountain. The final rule (74 FR 10811) incorporated a slightly different distribution for deep percolation than the draft rule, representing the effect of future climates for the period from 10,000 to one million years after repository closure. The NRC staff concluded that the slight change had no significant effect on repository performance.

The supplement discusses the NRC staff's constraints on the total amount of nonradiological contaminants available in the repository, focusing on materials like Alloy 22 and 316NG stainless steel. Corrosion rates and the resulting mass flux mobilized by corrosion are analyzed, with a detailed examination of the transport and breakthrough curves for contaminants such as Mo, Ni, and V.

The document discusses the source terms and mass flux of radiological and nonradiological contaminants from the proposed Yucca Mountain repository to various locations including Amargosa Farms and Furnace Creek in Death Valley. It also details the methodologies used by DOE in the 2008 SEIS and the NRC's evaluation.

Persons.name: Michael Berger
Persons.role: Attorney for the County of Inyo

Persons.name: Robert S. Hanna
Persons.role: Attorney for the County of Inyo

Organization.name: National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners

Project.summary: This appendix describes the estimation of mass flux of nonradiological contaminants applied to the regulatory compliance location over the entire one-million-year period. The release of contaminants from the repository is conservatively applied directly to the unsaturated-saturated zone boundary below the repository. Uranium is the only additional contaminant added due to its large quantity and high toxicity.
The document discusses the transport analysis for radiological and nonradiological contaminants beyond the regulatory compliance location, using the DVRFS model developed by the USGS.

The transport model incorporates processes of sorption, longitudinal dispersion, radioactive decay, and ingrowth, but excludes matrix diffusion and colloidal processes. The model uses sorption properties for each contaminant and flow path characteristics from the DVRFS model.
Project.technology: Analytical solution of the advection-dispersion equation

Project.summary: The document discusses the flow model and particle tracking results in the DVRFS model. It details the pathways and transport segments of contaminants from Amargosa Farms to various locations including Furnace Creek and Death Valley. The analysis includes both pre-pumping and pumping scenarios, highlighting different aquifer types and their transport properties.

The document discusses the estimation of contaminant concentrations in the aquifer environment between the regulatory compliance location and Amargosa Farms. It includes processes at surface discharge locations and describes an irrigation recycling model used to assess impacts at Amargosa Farms.
Project.capacity: Groundwater pumping at Amargosa Farms is on the order of 17,000 acre-ft/yr [21 million m3/yr].

Project.summary: The project involves the use of an irrigation recycling model to increase the amount of recycled groundwater. The model includes two factors: the amount of pumped water used for irrigation and the amount of irrigation water recaptured by pumping wells. The model assumes no decay of contaminants and no sorption to the aquifer during deep percolation, resulting in an increase in groundwater contaminant concentrations.

The document discusses dose conversion factors for the Amargosa Farms area, derived for a hypothetical individual (RMEI) to estimate maximum annual and lifetime doses. It also covers the impact of present-day and future wetter climates, natural surface discharge rates, and the effects of lateral and vertical dispersion along flow paths. Additionally, it mentions the irrigation recycling model and NRC staff's evaluation assumptions.

The J-13 well measured the volcanic aquifer below Fortymile Wash and upstream of the regulatory compliance location. The biosphere model includes exposure pathways and the conversion of contaminant levels to a dose or body uptake for each pathway.

The document discusses the intake of toxic chemicals from a repository and various environmental contexts, including agricultural communities, springs, and wet playas. It includes descriptions of exposure pathways and dose conversion factors.

The document discusses the exposure to contaminated water or evaporites, airborne particle concentration, and dose conversion factors for different climate states. It includes conservative assumptions used in model calculations to estimate the impact of contaminants.

The document discusses potential groundwater flow paths downstream of the compliance location, including natural groundwater surface discharge features such as springs, seeps, and playas. It also covers the ecological impact and chemical processes involved in groundwater discharge.

projectMetadata.name: Supplement to the U.S. Department of Energy’s Environmental Impact Statement for a Geologic Repository for the Disposal of Spent Nuclear Fuel and High-Level Radioactive Waste

Project.summary: This environment includes groundwater pumping for irrigation and groundwater use for a domestic and commercial water supply in an agricultural community. Presently, Amargosa Farms is the only location along the flow path from Yucca Mountain where extensive groundwater pumping occurs. The population eats locally grown food, both plants grown in fields and animals raised in the area, and works and lives in areas where the soils could become contaminated by water pumped for irrigation. Some fraction of the contaminants can leach back into the aquifer and possibly be recaptured by pumping wells, and some fraction would escape by soil erosion. In addition, decay and ingrowth will affect radionuclide concentrations. These processes are captured in the recycling irrigation model described in Section A.2.1.

The text discusses the effects of CO2 loss on groundwater pH and sorption onto soils and sediments, the processes at wet playas, and the concentration of contaminants in groundwater and surficial materials.
